metadata.case_name: Collector of Customs, Madras v. Respondent

facts.text: Respondent imported a large quantity of sewing machine needles under a licence.

Customs Department held that the licence did not cover the imported sewing machine needles, as they fell under Item 288 of Schedule I of Import Control Order, 1955 ('Needles for domestic sewing machines').
Customs authorities confiscated the imported needles and imposed a penalty of Rs. 5,000 on the respondent.
Central Government confirmed the confiscation order.
Single Judge of Madras High Court set aside the penalty but maintained the confiscation order, holding needles not proved to be prohibited.
Respondent appealed to Division Bench of Madras High Court against refusal to quash confiscation.
Division Bench quashed confiscation and penalty, holding no prohibition under Section 3 of Imports & Exports (Control) Act, 1947, as Import Control Order did not specify prohibition for these goods.
Respondent contended that imported needles could be used in both domestic and industrial sewing machines or were interchangeable, not confined to domestic only.
In Import Trade Control Policy (Red Book), 'nil' appeared against needles for domestic sewing machines for relevant year.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was a prohibition on import of needles for domestic sewing machines without a licence under Section 3 of Imports & Exports (Control) Act, 1947 and Clause 3 of Import Control Order, 1955.
Whether the respondent's import licence covered the particular goods imported (sewing machine needles claimed to be interchangeable).
Whether rules of natural justice were violated at the inquiry held by customs authorities.
Whether customs authorities acted in accordance with law in holding imported goods to be prohibited category.

petitioner_arguments.text: Clause 3 of Import Control Order, 1955 prohibits import of goods in Schedule I (including Item 288: Needles for domestic sewing machines) except under licence; imported needles fall under this.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Imports & Exports (Control) Act, 1947 Section 3; Import Control Order, 1955 Clause 3, Schedule I Item 288

petitioner_arguments.text: Prohibition is conditional and lifted only by valid licence covering the goods; respondent's licence did not cover.

respondent_arguments.text: No prohibition or restriction as contemplated by Section 3 of the Act, since Import Control Order did not specify these goods and policy showed 'nil'; needles interchangeable for domestic and industrial use.
Rules of natural justice violated at inquiry; needles not proved to be exclusively for domestic sewing machines.

court_reasoning.text: Section 3 of the Act and Clause 3 of Import Control Order impose unambiguous prohibition on import of Schedule I goods without licence; prohibition is conditional, lifted by licence permitting it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Language of Clause 3 prohibits unless under licence; 'nil' in Red Book does not override gazetted Control Order.

court_reasoning.text: Division Bench erred in holding no prohibition; reference to Red Book misled, as Control Order was duly notified.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishes case where no gazetted order existed.

court_reasoning.text: Division Bench did not decide if licence covered goods or natural justice violated; High Court can correct errors of law or remit if natural justice breached.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Real question is whether licence covers imported goods.

holdings.text: Prohibition exists under Clause 3 of Import Control Order, 1955 against import of needles for domestic sewing machines without licence.
Other undecided questions (licence coverage, natural justice) to be decided by Division Bench.

precedents_cited.case_name: Joint Chief Controller of Imports & Exports, Madras v. M/s. Amichand Mutha etc.
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Nil' in policy does not prohibit without gazetted order; here, Control Order was gazetted unlike that case.

statutes_cited.name: Imports & Exports (Control) Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers prohibition/restriction by gazetted order; all such goods deemed prohibited under Customs Act.

statutes_cited.name: Import Control Order, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits import of specified goods (domestic sewing machine needles) except under licence.

statutes_cited.name: Customs Act, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Applies to prohibited imports; licence utilisation if goods do not conform.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment of Division Bench of Madras High Court set aside; respondent's appeal restored to original number in High Court to be heard and decided in accordance with law on undecided issues.
outcome.relief_granted: Remitted to Division Bench for decision on merits, licence coverage, and natural justice.
outcome.costs: No costs of the appeal to this Court.

key_quotes.text: "no person shall import any goods of the description specified in Schedule I, except under, and in accordance with, a licence or a customs clearance permit" - Clause 3.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines the conditional prohibition central to the holding.

key_quotes.text: This language cannot have a meaning other than that the prohibition is there so long as goods of the description given in the schedule are not imported in accordance with an import licence.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Crux of court's interpretation of prohibition as conditional.

key_quotes.text: The prohibition is conditional in as much as it can be lifted by a licence which permits it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains nature of prohibition and frames key undecided issue.
